SOUND WAVES

Characteristics of Sound waves

1. Pressure: NB: the minimum discernible change in pressure that human beings can detect Is called the THRESHOLD OF HEARING and is 20 micro pascals; up to the THRESHOLD OF PAIN 20 pascal.

2. Intensity (I); this is the rate of flow of energy per unit area perpendicular to the direction of the sound wave. It is power per unit area. I =  

Intensity depends on power and varies inversely with the square of the distance away from the source

I =  

where , v = velocity of the sound wave

Intensity depends on pressure as well as the characteristics impedance of the medium. It is measure in watts per square meter.

3. Timbre: this is a measure of the quality of sound, usually of a musical tone. It enables to recognise a musical note from a violin or a guitar oral flute. It depends on waveform, frequency and intensity 

4.  Pitch: 1f the loudness of a tone remains constant, then pitch changes linearly with frequency. 

NB: A high frequency tone has a h1gh pitch and a low frequency tone has a low pitch 

5. Loudness Loudness 15 the way in which an individual perceive the intensity of a note at a Particular frequency. It is determined largely by its intensity. 

Echo

 This is the reflection of sound wave

Applications of echo are 

l. Determination of sound wave in air.

NB: velocity of sound in air = ; where d is distance; tis the time (t) seconds

2. Echo is used in medical diagnosis

3. Determining the depth of a sea or ocean or river

4. Prospecting for mineral such as oil. for

Beat

Beat is produced by the interference of two waves with almost identical frequencies. Beat = f1 – f2. 

The presence of beats between two notes enhances the pleasure of listening to musical notes.

A Sonometer is a device for demonstrating the relationship between the frequency of the sound produced by a plucked string, and the tension, length and mass per unit length of the string. 

The relationship between frequency and length is an inversely proportional. This means that if the length is doubled the frequency is halved.

Acoustic echo sounders are used to measure the depth of the sea by using echo of sound as measure. The instrument transmits a 10 -30KHz sound that gets reflected from the sea floor. The echo reflected from the sea floor determines the depth of the sea in consideration.

Superposition states that the amplitude caused by two or more waves traversing the same space, is the sum of the amplitudes which would have been produced by the individual waves separately. In other words, it is the combining of waves.

If both tuning forks are vibrated together, then they produce sounds with slightly different frequencies. These sounds will interfere to produce detectable beats. The closer the two frequencies, the lower the beat frequency, and this will become zero when they are perfectly in tune.

Beat frequency (f) = f2 - f1

 

Example

Under constant tension and constant mass per unit length, the note produced by a plucked string is 500Hz when the-length of the wire is 0.9m. At what length is the frequency 150Hz?

A. 3m, B. 0.27m, C. 8.33m, D. 6740m

A (2007/2008, no 7)

The relationship between frequency and length is an inversely proportional. This means that if the length is doubled the frequency is halved. This holds when tension and mass per unit length are kept constant.

f  1/L

fL = k

making L2 the subject we have

L2 = 

= 500Hz, L1 = 0.9m, L2 =?, f2 = 150Hz 

L2 =  = 3

L2 = 3m

 

The tone of lowest frequency is called Fundamental frequency and other tones are known as OVERTONES OR HARMONICS. The loudness of sound depends upon the amplitude of vibration. And pitch determined by its fundamental frequency.

The fundamental frequency of a vibrating string is inversely proportional to the square root of the mass per unit length. This means that of two strings of the same material and with the same length and tension, the thicker string has the lower fundamental frequency.

The loudness of sound depends upon the amplitude of vibration. And pitch determined by its fundamental frequency. Two or more sound may have the same loudness and the same pitch but that they may differ in number and relative intensities of overtones. The quality of sound depends upon the wave from of the resultants.

A. 15°, B. 18°, C. 22°, D. 240˚
